steps.title: User Actions Begin
steps.narration: Progress tracking starts with user actions. Scrolling through content, answering quizzes, completing drag-drop activities.

steps.title: ProgressTracker
steps.narration: ProgressTracker watches scrolling behavior. It uses IntersectionObserver to detect which sections users have viewed.

steps.title: ActivityTracker
steps.narration: ActivityTracker handles interactive elements. Quiz answers, drag completions, code challengesâ€”every interaction is captured.

steps.title: Data Persistence
steps.narration: Both trackers feed into DataService. Progress and activity data flows to Firestore for permanent storage.

steps.title: UI Updates
steps.narration: As data changes, UI updates follow. Progress bars fill, completion indicators appear, toast notifications celebrate achievements!

steps.title: Page Load
steps.narration: The lesson page loads. ProgressTracker needs to know what sections exist before it can track them.

steps.title: Tracker Initializes
steps.narration: ProgressTracker.init kicks off the discovery process. Time to find all trackable sections on the page!

steps.title: Query Selectors
steps.narration: querySelectorAll finds all elements with data-section attributes. These are our trackable content sections.

steps.title: Sections Array
steps.narration: All discovered sections are stored in an array. This becomes the denominator for progress calculation.

steps.title: Observer Setup
steps.narration: Finally, IntersectionObserver is created and attached to each section. Scroll tracking is now active!

steps.title: User Scrolls
steps.narration: The user scrolls through lesson content. Every movement could reveal new sections and advance progress.

steps.title: Observer Monitors
steps.narration: IntersectionObserver watches visibility changes. Unlike scroll events, it only fires when thresholds are crossed. Efficient!

steps.title: Visibility Check
steps.narration: When a section crosses 50 percent visibility, isIntersecting returns true. The section has been meaningfully viewed.

steps.title: Mark as Viewed
steps.narration: The section ID is added to the viewedSections Set. Sets prevent duplicatesâ€”view a section twice, it still only counts once.

steps.title: Debounced Save
steps.narration: Progress is saved with debouncingâ€”multiple rapid views trigger just one Firestore write. Network efficiency!

steps.title: ActivityTracker Hub
steps.narration: ActivityTracker is the hub for all interactive elements. It discovers activities on page load and tracks their completion.

steps.title: Quiz Activities
steps.narration: Quizzes use data-answer attributes to define correct answers. ActivityTracker validates user selections and records attempts.

steps.title: Drag & Drop
steps.narration: Drag-drop activities use data-target to map items to zones. Drop an item in the right zoneâ€”activity complete!

steps.title: Code Challenges
steps.narration: Code challenges have data-solution attributes. User code is compared against expected output for validation.

steps.title: Firestore Storage
steps.narration: Every attempt is saved to Firestore's activityAttempts subcollection. Complete history of engagement!

steps.title: Activity Attempt
steps.narration: A user completes an activity. But waitâ€”what if they're offline? The internet isn't always reliable!

steps.title: Connection Check
steps.narration: navigator.onLine tells us the connection status. Online? Save directly. Offline? Time for the queue!

steps.title: Queue for Later
steps.narration: Offline attempts go into a queue. The activity is stored locally, waiting for reconnection.

steps.title: LocalStorage Backup
steps.narration: The queue persists in LocalStorage. Even if the browser closes, queued attempts survive.

steps.title: Connection Restored
steps.narration: The online event fires when connection returns. Time to sync those queued attempts!

steps.title: Sync Process
steps.narration: syncQueuedAttempts processes the queue. Each pending attempt is saved to Firestore, then removed from the queue.

steps.title: Raw Lesson Data
steps.narration: Analytics starts with raw data from Firestore. Lesson completion records tell us what content users have consumed.

steps.title: Learning Velocity
steps.narration: calcVelocity computes learning speed. Lessons completed per week, multiplied by 20, gives a 0-100 velocity score.

steps.title: Quiz Mastery
steps.narration: calcMastery averages quiz performance. Correct answers divided by total attemptsâ€”expressed as a percentage.

steps.title: Active Streak
steps.narration: calcStreak counts consecutive days with activity. Miss a day? Streak resets. Consistency is rewarded!

steps.title: Cognitive Score
steps.narration: The Cognitive Score combines all metrics with weights: 40 percent mastery, 30 percent velocity, 20 percent streak, 10 percent completion.

steps.title: 90% Threshold
steps.narration: Progress hits 90 percent! This is the magic thresholdâ€”the lesson is essentially complete when this milestone is reached.

steps.title: Already Complete?
steps.narration: Before celebrating, we check if the lesson was already marked complete. No duplicate celebrations!

steps.title: Mark Complete
steps.narration: markLessonComplete sets the completion flag. This is a one-time operation per lesson.

steps.title: Event Dispatch
steps.narration: A lessonComplete event broadcasts to the app. Other components can reactâ€”update UI, show notifications, unlock content.

steps.title: Celebration Toast!
steps.narration: A toast notification appears celebrating the achievement. Visual feedback motivates continued learning!

steps.title: Streak Updated
steps.narration: Finally, the user's streak is refreshed. Completing a lesson counts as daily activity. Keep that streak alive!

questions.question: Why is IntersectionObserver better than scroll event listeners?
options: It only fires when thresholds are crossed
questions.explanation: IntersectionObserver is efficient because it only fires callbacks when visibility thresholds are crossed, unlike scroll events which fire continuously.

questions.question: What visibility percentage marks a section as 'viewed'?
questions.explanation: When 50% of a section is visible, isIntersecting returns true and the section is marked as viewed.

questions.question: Where are offline activity attempts stored?
questions.explanation: Queued attempts persist in LocalStorage, surviving browser closes until connection is restored.

questions.question: What triggers the sync of queued attempts?
questions.explanation: The 'online' window event fires when connection is restored, triggering syncQueuedAttempts.

questions.question: What is the formula for Learning Velocity?
questions.explanation: Learning Velocity is calculated as lessons completed per week, multiplied by 20, giving a 0-100 score.

questions.question: What weight does Mastery have in the Cognitive Score?
questions.explanation: Mastery has the highest weight at 40% in the Cognitive Score formula.
